title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement jeffrey.r.stevens@protonmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to cocoon
text: outlines propose change cocoon.

title: Contributing to cocoon
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to cocoon
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See tidyverse guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to cocoon
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("JeffreyRStevens/cocoon", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). Make changes, commit git, create PR. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to cocoon
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to cocoon
text: Please note cocoon project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: cocoon
text: Running statistical test R typically returns list lots information test, often including things like statistical test values p-values. aim format_stats() function extract format statistics suite commonly used statistical objects (correlation t-tests).

title: cocoon
text: format_stats() function can input objects returned cor.test() correlation::correlation() function detects whether object Pearson, Kendall, Spearman correlation. reports formats appropriate correlation coefficient p-value. Let’s start creating different correlations. Pearson correlations, get correlation coefficient confidence intervals. Since Spearman Kendall correlations non-parametric, confidence intervals returned. Confidence intervals can omitted Pearson correlations setting full = FALSE. Format number digits coefficients digits digits p-values pdigits. Include leading zeros coefficients p-values pzero = TRUE. Remove italics italics = FALSE.
code: mpg_disp_corr_pearson <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp, method = "pearson") mpg_disp_corr_spearman <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp, method = "spearman", exact = FALSE) mpg_disp_corr_kendall <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp, method = "kendall", exact = FALSE)

title: cocoon
text: format_stats() function can also input objects returned t.test() wilcox.test() functions detect whether object Student’s Wilcoxon t-test, including one-sample, independent-sample, paired-sample versions. reports formats mean value (mean difference), confidence intervals mean value/difference, appropriate test statistic, degrees freedom (parametric tests), p-value. Let’s start creating different t-tests Student’s t-tests, get mean value difference confidence intervals. Means confidence intervals can omitted setting full = FALSE. Format number digits coefficients digits digits p-values pdigits. Include leading zeros coefficients p-values pzero = TRUE. Remove italics italics = FALSE.
code: mpg_disp_ttest_gear_carb <- t.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb) mpg_disp_ttest_gear_carb_paired <- t.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb, paired = TRUE) mpg_disp_ttest_gear_carb_onesample <- t.test(mtcars$gear, mu = 4) mpg_disp_wtest_gear_carb <- wilcox.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb, exact = FALSE) mpg_disp_wtest_gear_carb_paired <- wilcox.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb, paired = TRUE, exact = FALSE) mpg_disp_wtest_gear_carb_onesample <- wilcox.test(mtcars$gear, mu = 4, exact = FALSE)

title: cocoon
text: format_stats() function can also extract format Bayes factors BFBayesFactor object {BayesFactor} package. Bayes factors standardized formatted. One issue Bayes factors can referenced either alternative hypothesis (H1) null hypothesis (H0). Also, ratio, digits decimal important 1 1. respond digits issue, format_stats() function controls digits Bayes factors less 1 (digits1) separately greater 1 (digits2). fact, defaults different two arguments. , Bayes factors can large small evidence strongly favors one hypothesis another. Therefore, cutoff argument set threshold (1/cutoff) returned value truncated (e.g., BF > 1000). default label Bayes factors BF10. text label can changed label argument, setting label = "" omits label. Italics can removed italics = FALSE, subscript can set 01 (subscript = "01") removed (subscript = "").
code: bf_corr <- BayesFactor::correlationBF(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp) bf_ttest <- BayesFactor::ttestBF(mtcars$vs, mtcars$am) bf_lm <- BayesFactor::lmBF(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars)

previous_headings: Formatting statistical values > Central tendency and error
title: cocoon
text: Often, need include simple descriptive statistics documents, measures central tendency error. cocoon includes suite functions can calculate different summary measures central tendency (mean median) error (confidence interval, standard error, standard deviation, interquartile range) numeric data vector. base function format_summary(), can specify central tendency summary argument error error argument. instance, format_summary(vec, summary = "mean", error = "se") calculates mean standard error. cocoon includes number wrapper functions cover common measures central tendency error including: format_meanci() format_meanse() format_meansd() format_medianiqr() don’t want include error, use format_mean() format_median().

previous_headings: Formatting statistical values > Central tendency and error
title: cocoon
text: addition calculating values directly vectors, functions can format already-calculated measures. already mean error calculated, just pass vector central tendency, lower error limit, upper error limit values argument format . instance, format_meanci(values = c(12.5, 11.2, 13.7)) produces M = 12.5, 95% CI [11.2, 13.7]. Make sure pass arguments order, function checks whether send argument less equal first third greater equal first.

previous_headings: Formatting statistical values > Central tendency and error
title: cocoon
text: functions can control many aspects formatting values labels summary statistics. Digits decimal controlled digits (default 1). tendlabel argument defines whether default abbreviation used (“M” “Mdn”), full word (“Mean” “Median”), label provided. can italicized italics argument, subscripts can included subscript argument, units added units argument. Error can displayed number different ways. Setting display argument "limits" (default) includes upper lower limits brackets. intervals rather limits preferred, can appended mean/median ± using "pm" parentheses "par". Error displayed display = "none". presence error label controlled logical argument errorlabel. set FALSE, error label included. confidence intervals, cilevel argument takes numeric scalar 0-1 define confidence level.

title: cocoon
text: P-values pretty easy format format_p(). digits argument controls number digits decimal, value lower, p < used. Unfortunately, APA style involves lopping leading zero p-values, setting pzero  = TRUE turns silly setting. p-value label controlled label, user can specify exact label text. default, lower case, italicized p. Non-italicized can defined italics = FALSE. P-value labels can omitted setting label = "".

title: cocoon
text: Though format_stats() function extracts formats Bayes factors {BayesFactor} package, sometimes may Bayes factors sources. format_bf() function formats Bayes factors numeric values (either single scalar elements vectors).

title: cocoon
text: addition formatting specific statistics, package can format numbers generally. format_num() function controls general formatting numbers digits digits presence leading zero pzero. large small values, using scientific notation may useful way format numbers. format_scientific() function converts scientific notation, offering control number digits well whether output type Markdown LaTeX.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jeffrey R. Stevens. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Stevens JR (2024). cocoon: Extract, format, print statistical output. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/cocoon.
code: @Manual{,   title = {cocoon: Extract, format, and print statistical output},   author = {Jeffrey R. Stevens},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/cocoon}, }

what: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: goal cocoon provide functions flexibly format statistical output way can inserted R Markdown Quarto documents. analogous apa_print() functions {papaja} package, functions cocoon can print Markdown LaTeX syntax. output document PDF, doesn’t matter. output document Word document (required many journal publishers), Markdown syntax generates editable output instead image output. default style statistical output follows American Psychological Association style, many defaults can -ridden flexibly format output.

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: can install stable released version cocoon CRAN : can install development version cocoon GitHub :
code: install.packages("cocoon") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("JeffreyRStevens/cocoon")

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: example, ’ll create correlation mtcars data set. Now can apply format_stats() function cars_corr create Markdown-formatted character string statistical results. can embed inline R Markdown code generate results.
code: library(cocoon) (cars_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp)) #>  #>  Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  mtcars$mpg and mtcars$disp #> t = -8.7472, df = 30, p-value = 9.38e-10 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.9233594 -0.7081376 #> sample estimates: #>        cor  #> -0.8475514

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (`r format_stats(cars_corr)`).

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (r = -.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], p < .001).

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: can also alter output allow formatting. instance, may like APA’s silly rule remove leading zeros value exceed 1 (like correlations p-values). may want include confidence limits around correlation coefficient. Finally, maybe don’t want statistics labels italicized.

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (`r format_stats(cars_corr, pzero = TRUE, full = FALSE, italics = FALSE)`).

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (r = -0.85, p < 0.001).

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: Correlations (output cor.test() correlation::correlation(), including Pearson’s, Kendall’s, Spearman’s correlations) Student t-tests, Wilcoxon rank sum, signed rank tests (output t.test() wilcox.test(), including one-sample, two-sample independent, paired tests) Bayes factors (output {BayesFactor} package) format_summary(): Means error (calculates vector uses vector mean error interval mean, lower error limit, upper error limit) format_p(): P-values format_bf(): Bayes factors (numerics) format_scientific(): Scientific notation format_num(): numbers format_chr(): Italicize character strings

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: {papaja} - package uses apa_print() function convert number R statistical objects R Markdown output. However, outputs LaTeX syntax generates APA formatted output minimal flexibility alter output. {apa} - package also converts R statistical objects R Markdown output. allows output format Markdown, also generates APA formatted output minimal flexibility alter output. {insight} - package extracts information model objects. includes format_p() format_bf() functions achieves similar goals package, allow much control formatting labels values.

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: cite cocoon, use: Stevens, Jeffrey R. (2024). cocoon: Extract, format, print statistical output. (version 0.1.0) https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/cocoon

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: Contributions cocoon welcome! Feel free check open issues ideas. pull requests encouraged, may want raise issue contact maintainer first. Please note cocoon project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output
text: package name cocoon captures main goal transforming statistical inputs nicely formatted outputs. mirrors cocoons, caterpillars build transform beautiful adult insects. Cocoons formally defined case larvae moths spin around pupa. cocoons cases built moths insects, whereas butterflies produce chrysalis, forms skin.  Photo source: Silk moths Wikimedia Commons

what: cocoon: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output — cocoon-package
title: cocoon: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output — cocoon-package
text: Provides functions format statistical output way can inserted R Markdown documents. analogous apa_print() functions 'papaja' package prints Markdown LaTeX syntax.

title: cocoon: Extract, Format, and Print Statistical Output — cocoon-package
text: Maintainer: Jeffrey R. Stevens jeffrey.r.stevens@protonmail.com (ORCID) [copyright holder]

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: format_bf() can input either BayesFactor object vector Bayes factor values. default, function rounds Bayes factors greater 1 one decimal place Bayes factors less 1 two decimal places. Values greater 1000 less 1/1000 formatted using scientific notation. Cutoffs can set format values greater less cutoffs (e.g., BF > 1000 BF < 0.001). Numbers digits, cutoffs, italics, label subscripts customizable.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
code: format_bf(   x,   digits1 = 1,   digits2 = 2,   cutoff = NULL,   label = "BF",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = "10",   type = "md" )

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: x BayesFactor object vector numeric Bayes factor values digits1 Number digits decimal Bayes factors > 1 digits2 Number digits decimal Bayes factors < 1 cutoff Cutoff using _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> (value must > 1) label Character string label Bayes factor. Default BF. Set label = "" return just formatted Bayes factor value label operator (=, <, >) italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether label italicized (BF BF) subscript Subscript include BF label ("10", "01", "" subscript) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: character string includes label (default BF~10~) Bayes factor formatted Markdown LaTeX. Bayes factor cutoff, _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> used.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
code: # Format BFBayesfactor objects from {BayesFactor} package format_bf(BayesFactor::lmBF(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars)) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 87.3"  # Format Bayes factors > 1 format_bf(12.4444) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 12.4"  # Bayes factors > 1000 will use scientific notation format_bf(1244.44) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.2×10^3^"  # Control digits for Bayes factors > 1 with digits1 format_bf(1244.44, digits1 = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.244×10^3^"  # Control cutoff for output format_bf(1244.44, cutoff = 10000) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1244.4"  # Format Bayes factors < 1 format_bf(0.111) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.11"  # Bayes factors < 0.001 will use scientific notation format_bf(0.0001) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.0×10^-4^"  # Control digits for Bayes factors < 1 with digits2 format_bf(0.111, digits2 = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.111"  # Control cutoff for output format_bf(0.001, cutoff = 100) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ < 0.01"  # Return only Bayes factor value (no label) format_bf(12.4444, label = "") #> [1] "12.4"  # Format for LaTeX format_bf(12.4444, type = "latex") #> [1] "$BF$$_{10}$ = 12.4"

what: Format character strings with italics and type — format_chr
title: Format character strings with italics and type — format_chr
text: Format character strings italics type

title: Format character strings with italics and type — format_chr
code: format_chr(x, italics = TRUE, type = "md")

title: Format character strings with italics and type — format_chr
text: x Character string italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether text italicized type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format character strings with italics and type — format_chr
text: character string either Markdown LaTeX formatting italics .

title: Format character strings with italics and type — format_chr
code: format_chr("Hello world!") #> [1] "_Hello world!_" # Format in LaTeX syntax format_chr("Hello world!", type = "latex") #> [1] "$Hello world!$" # Remove italics format_chr("Hello world!", italics = FALSE) #> [1] "Hello world!"

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: format_corr() can format correlation statistics generated cor.test() output. now internal function superceded format_stats(), recommend using instead.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
code: format_corr(x, digits, pdigits, pzero, full, italics, type, ...)

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: x htest object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, test statistics pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical value (default = FALSE) whether include leading zero p-values full Logical value (default = TRUE) whether include means confidence intervals just test statistic p-value italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether p label italicized type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX) ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
code: # format_stats(cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl))

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: Format numbers

title: Format numbers — format_num
code: format_num(x, digits = 1, pzero = TRUE)

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: x Number digits Number digits decimal pzero Logical value (default = TRUE) whether include leading zero numbers less 1

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: character string formatting number specified number digits decimal.

title: Format numbers — format_num
code: format_num(pi, digits = 2) #> [1] "3.14" format_num(pi, digits = 4) #> [1] "3.1416"

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: format_p() inputs numeric vectors p-values. Cutoffs can set format values less cutoffs (e.g., p < 0.001). default output APA formatted, numbers digits, cutoffs, leading zeros, italics customizable.

title: Format p-values — format_p
code: format_p(   x,   digits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   label = "p",   italics = TRUE,   type = "md" )

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: x Number representing p-value digits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical value (default = FALSE) whether include leading zero p-values label Character string label p value. Default p. Set label = "" return just formatted p value label operator (=, <, >) italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether label italicized (p) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: character string includes p p-value formatted Markdown LaTeX. p-value digits cutoff, p < cutoff used.

title: Format p-values — format_p
code: # Format p-value format_p(0.001) #> [1] "_p_ = .001"  # Format p-value vector format_p(c(0.001, 0.01)) #> [1] "_p_ = .001" "_p_ = .010"  # Round digits for p-values greater than cutoff format_p(0.111, digits = 2) #> [1] "_p_ = .11"  # Default cutoff is p < 0.001 format_p(0.0001) #> [1] "_p_ < .001"  # Set cutoff with digits format_p(0.0001, digits = 2) #> [1] "_p_ < .01"  # Include leading zero format_p(0.001, pzero = TRUE) #> [1] "_p_ = 0.001"  # Return only Bayes factor value (no label) format_p(0.001, label = "") #> [1] ".001"  # Format for LaTeX format_p(0.001, type = "latex") #> [1] "$p$ = .001"

what: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: Format numbers scientific notation

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
code: format_scientific(x, digits = 1, type = "md")

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: x Number digits Number digits decimal type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: character string number scientific notation formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
code: format_scientific(1111) #> [1] "1.1×10^3^" # Control number of digits after decimal with digits format_scientific(1111, digits = 3) #> [1] "1.111×10^3^"

title: Format Bayes factors — format_stats.BFBayesFactor
text: method formats Bayes factors {BayesFactor} package. default, function rounds Bayes factors greater 1 one decimal place Bayes factors less 1 two decimal places. Values greater 1000 less 1/1000 formatted using scientific notation. Cutoffs can set format values greater less cutoffs (e.g., BF > 1000 BF < 0.001). Numbers digits, cutoffs, italics, label subscripts customizable.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_stats.BFBayesFactor
code: # S3 method for class 'BFBayesFactor' format_stats(   x,   digits1 = 1,   digits2 = 2,   cutoff = NULL,   label = "BF",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = "10",   type = "md",   ... )

title: Format Bayes factors — format_stats.BFBayesFactor
text: x BayesFactor object vector numeric Bayes factor values digits1 Number digits decimal Bayes factors > 1 digits2 Number digits decimal Bayes factors < 1 cutoff Cutoff using _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> (value must > 1) label Character string label Bayes factor. Default BF. Set label = "" return just formatted Bayes factor value label operator (=, <, >) italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether label italicized (BF BF) subscript Subscript include BF label ("10", "01", "" subscript) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX) ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_stats.BFBayesFactor
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_stats.BFBayesFactor
code: # Prepare statistical object test_bf <- BayesFactor::ttestBF(mtcars$vs, mtcars$am)  # Format Bayes factor format_stats(test_bf) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.26"  # Control cutoff for output format_stats(test_bf, cutoff = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ < 0.33"  # Change digits, remove italics and subscript format_stats(test_bf, digits2 = 1, italics = FALSE, subscript = "") #> [1] "BF = 0.3"  # Return only Bayes factor value (no label) format_stats(test_bf, label = "") #> [1] "0.26"  # Format for LaTeX format_stats(test_bf, type = "latex") #> [1] "$BF$$_{10}$ = 0.26"

title: Format correlation statistics — format_stats.easycorrelation
text: functions formats correlation statistics generated {correlation} package. detects whether object Pearson, Spearman, Kendall correlation reports appropriate correlation label (r, \(\tau\), \(\rho\)). default output APA formatted, numbers digits, leading zeros, presence confidence intervals, italics customizable.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_stats.easycorrelation
code: # S3 method for class 'easycorrelation' format_stats(   x,   digits = 2,   pdigits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   full = TRUE,   italics = TRUE,   type = "md",   ... )

title: Format correlation statistics — format_stats.easycorrelation
text: x htest object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, test statistics pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical value (default = FALSE) whether include leading zero p-values full Logical value (default = TRUE) whether include means confidence intervals just test statistic p-value italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether p label italicized type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX) ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_stats.easycorrelation
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_stats.easycorrelation
code: # Prepare statistical objects test_corr <- correlation::correlation(mtcars, select = "mpg", select2 = "disp") test_corr2 <- correlation::correlation(mtcars, select = "mpg", select2 = "disp", method = "kendall")  # Format correlation format_stats(test_corr) #> [1] "_r_ = -.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], _p_ < .001"  # Remove confidence intervals and italics format_stats(test_corr, full = FALSE, italics = FALSE) #> [1] "r = -.85, p < .001"  # Change digits and add leading zero to p-value format_stats(test_corr, digits = 3, pdigits = 4, pzero = TRUE) #> [1] "_r_ = -0.848, 95% CI [-0.923, -0.708], _p_ < 1e-04"  # Format Kendall's tau for LaTeX format_stats(test_corr2, type = "latex") #> [1] "$τ$ = -.77, $p$ < .001"

title: Format hypothesis test statistics — format_stats.htest
text: method formats hypothesis test statistics class htest. Currently, includes correlations cor.test() t-tests Wilcoxon tests t.test() wilcox.test(). correlations, function detects whether object Pearson, Spearman, Kendall correlation reports appropriate correlation label (r, \(\tau\), \(\rho\)). default output APA formatted, function allows control numbers digits, leading zeros, presence means confidence intervals, italics, degrees freedom, mean labels, output format Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format hypothesis test statistics — format_stats.htest
code: # S3 method for class 'htest' format_stats(   x,   digits = NULL,   pdigits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   full = TRUE,   italics = TRUE,   dfs = "par",   mean = "abbr",   type = "md",   ... )

title: Format hypothesis test statistics — format_stats.htest
text: x htest object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, test statistics pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical value (default = FALSE) whether include leading zero p-values full Logical value (default = TRUE) whether include means confidence intervals just test statistic p-value italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether p label italicized dfs Formatting degrees freedom ("par" = parenthetical, "sub" = subscript, "none" = print degrees freedom) mean Formatting mean label ("abbr" = M, "word" = Mean) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX) ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Format hypothesis test statistics — format_stats.htest
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format hypothesis test statistics — format_stats.htest
code: # Prepare statistical objects test_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl) test_corr2 <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl, method = "kendall") #> Warning: Cannot compute exact p-value with ties test_ttest <- t.test(mtcars$vs, mtcars$am) test_ttest2 <- wilcox.test(mtcars$vs, mtcars$am) #> Warning: cannot compute exact p-value with ties  # Format correlation format_stats(test_corr) #> [1] "_r_ = -.85, 95% CI [-0.93, -0.72], _p_ < .001"  # Remove confidence intervals and italics format_stats(test_corr, full = FALSE, italics = FALSE) #> [1] "r = -.85, p < .001"  # Change digits and add leading zero to p-value format_stats(test_corr, digits = 3, pdigits = 4, pzero = TRUE) #> [1] "_r_ = -0.852, 95% CI [-0.926, -0.716], _p_ < 1e-04"  # Format Kendall's tau format_stats(test_corr2) #> [1] "_τ_ = -.80, _p_ < .001"  # Format t-test   format_stats(test_ttest) #> [1] "_M_ = 0.0, 95% CI [-0.2, 0.3], _t_(62) = 0.2, _p_ = .804"  # Remove mean and confidence interval format_stats(test_ttest, full = FALSE) #> [1] "_t_(62) = 0.2, _p_ = .804"  # Remove degrees of freedom and spell out "Mean" format_stats(test_ttest, dfs = "none", mean = "word") #> [1] "_Mean_ = 0.0, 95% CI [-0.2, 0.3], _t_ = 0.2, _p_ = .804"  # Format for LaTeX format_stats(test_ttest2, type = "latex") #> [1] "$W$ = 528.0, $p$ = .808"

title: Format statistical results — format_stats
text: generic function takes objects various statistical methods create formatted character strings insert R Markdown Quarto documents. Currently, generic function works following objects: htest objects correlations, t-tests, Wilcoxon tests correlations {correlation} package. Bayes factors {BayesFactor} package. function invokes specific methods depend class first argument.

title: Format statistical results — format_stats
code: format_stats(x, ...)

title: Format statistical results — format_stats
text: x Statistical object. ... Additional arguments passed methods. method-specific arguments, see format_stats.htest() htest correlations, t-tests, Wilcoxon tests format_stats.BFBayesFactor() Bayes factors {BayesFactor} package.

title: Format statistical results — format_stats
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format statistical results — format_stats
code: # Format cor.test() object format_stats(cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl)) #> [1] "_r_ = -.85, 95% CI [-0.93, -0.72], _p_ < .001"  # Format correlation::correlation() object format_stats(correlation::correlation(data = mtcars, select = "mpg", select2 = "cyl")) #> [1] "_r_ = -.85, 95% CI [-0.93, -0.72], _p_ < .001"  # Format t.test() object format_stats(t.test(mtcars$vs, mtcars$am)) #> [1] "_M_ = 0.0, 95% CI [-0.2, 0.3], _t_(62) = 0.2, _p_ = .804"  # Format BFBayesFactor object from {BayesFactor} package format_stats(BayesFactor::ttestBF(mtcars$vs, mtcars$am)) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.26"

title: Format subscript text — format_sub
text: Format subscript text

title: Format subscript text — format_sub
code: format_sub(subscript = NULL, type = "md")

title: Format subscript text — format_sub
text: subscript Character string NULL type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format subscript text — format_sub
text: character string formatted subscript either Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format subscript text — format_sub
code: format_sub("Hello world!") #> [1] "~Hello world!~" # Format in LaTeX syntax format_sub("Hello world!", type = "latex") #> [1] "$_{Hello world!}$"

what: Calculate and format summary statistics of central tendency and error — format_summary
title: Calculate and format summary statistics of central tendency and error — format_summary
text: format_summary() general function allows either automatically calculate mean/median measure error data vector specify already calculated mean/median either error interval error limits. Error measures include confidence intervals, standard deviation, standard error mean. specific function formats means error measures using APA (7th edition) style. format_meanci(), format_meansd(), format_meanse(), format_medianiqr() wrappers around format_summary() specific error measures default style. just format mean median error, use format_mean() format_median(). measures ignore NAs.

title: Calculate and format summary statistics of central tendency and error — format_summary
code: format_summary(   x = NULL,   tendency = "mean",   error = "ci",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "limits",   cilevel = 0.95,   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_mean(   x = NULL,   tendency = "mean",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "none",   type = "md" )  format_meanci(   x = NULL,   tendency = "mean",   error = "ci",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "limits",   cilevel = 0.95,   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_meanse(   x = NULL,   tendency = "mean",   error = "se",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "par",   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_meansd(   x = NULL,   tendency = "mean",   error = "sd",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "par",   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_median(   x = NULL,   tendency = "median",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "none",   type = "md" )  format_medianiqr(   x = NULL,   tendency = "median",   error = "iqr",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   tendlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "par",   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )

title: Calculate and format summary statistics of central tendency and error — format_summary
text: x Numeric vector data calculate mean error tendency Character vector specifying measure central tendency ("mean" = mean, "median" = median) error Character vector specifying error type ("ci" = confidence interval, "se" = standard error mean, "sd" = standard deviation, "iqr" = interquartile range) values Numeric vector mean interval mean lower upper limits digits Number digits decimal means error tendlabel Formatting tendency label ("abbr" = M, "word" = Mean, "none" = label) italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether mean label italicized subscript Character string include subscript mean label units Character string gives units include mean value display Character vector specifying display error ("limits" = [lower limit, upper limit], "pm" = ±interval, "par" = (interval), "none" = display error) cilevel Numeric scalar 0-1 defining confidence level (defaults 0.95) errorlabel Logical value (default = TRUE) whether error label (e.g., 95% CI) included type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Calculate and format summary statistics of central tendency and error — format_summary
text: character string mean error formatted Markdown LaTeX. return mean (error), set display = "none".

title: Calculate and format summary statistics of central tendency and error — format_summary
code: # Print mean and 95% confidence limits for fuel efficiency format_meanci(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1, 95% CI [17.9, 22.3]"  # Print mean and standard deviation format_meansd(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 (_SD_ = 6.0)"  # Print mean and standard error of the mean format_meanse(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 (_SE_ = 1.1)"  # Print mean format_mean(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1"  # Print mean and 95% confidence limits with no label for "95% CI" format_meanci(mtcars$mpg, errorlabel = FALSE) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1,  [17.9, 22.3]"  # Print mean and standard error of the mean as plus/minus interval format_meanse(mtcars$mpg, error = "se", display = "pm") #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 ± 1.1"  # Print mean and 90% confidence limits with units format_meanci(mtcars$mpg, units = "cm", cilevel = 0.9) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 cm, 90% CI [18.3, 21.9]"  # Print three-digit mean with subscript in LaTeX format_summary(mtcars$mpg, digits = 3, subscript = "control", display = "none", type = "latex") #> [1] "$M$$_{control}$ = 20.091"

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: format_ttest() can format t-tests generated t.test() wilcox.test() output. now internal function superceded format_stats(), recommend using instead.

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
code: format_ttest(x, digits, pdigits, pzero, full, italics, dfs, mean, type)

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: x htest object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, test statistics pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical value (default = FALSE) whether include leading zero p-values full Logical value (default = TRUE) whether include means confidence intervals just test statistic p-value italics Logical value (default = TRUE) whether p label italicized dfs Formatting degrees freedom ("par" = parenthetical, "sub" = subscript, "none" = print degrees freedom) mean Formatting mean label ("abbr" = M, "word" = Mean) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
code: format_stats(t.test(formula = mtcars$mpg ~ mtcars$vs)) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.9, 95% CI [-11.5, -4.4], _t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < .001"

title: cocoon 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-11-05

title: cocoon 0.1.0
text: Added format_stats() function apply accepted statistical objects (correlations, t-tests, Bayes factors). generic function recognizes object class uses appropriate method, supercedes format_corr() format_ttest(). format_bf() can still used format numeric type Bayes factors. Added ability format output correlation::correlation().

title: cocoon 0.1.0
text: Reorder sections vignette. Improve spacing comments examples. Add alt text images.

title: cocoon 0.1.0
text: Move string building internal build_string() function. Split functions separate format_stats, format_statvalues, format_summary scripts

title: cocoon 0.0.1
text: Initial release cocoon.
